set_calculator

Class calculator

  • java.lang.Object
    • set_calculator.calculator

  • public class calculator
extends java.lang.Object
    This class asks for two sets A and B and applies three different kind of operations on them. (Union, Difference and Intersection)

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      calculator()

      Searches for a set and builds it when user input is valid

      This procedure displays the rules of the Sets Calculator

      Main function calls the display function, manage the number of lines and the end of the program.

      Parses the input in Set A, operator and Set B then launches the operation on the sets.

      • calculator

        public calculator()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Main function calls the display function, manage the number of lines and the end of the program. User can quit the program when he wants by pressing return.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - any exceptions launched during the program execution

      • parseLineInSets

        public static void parseLineInSets()
        Parses the input in Set A, operator and Set B then launches the operation on the sets.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when the operator is not found

      • setCalculation

        public static void setCalculation(java.util.TreeSet<java.lang.Integer> A,
                  java.util.TreeSet<java.lang.Integer> B,
                  char operator)
        Applies the operator's function on the sets and print the result
        Parameters:
        A - the first set parse from the input line
        B - the second set parse from the input line
        operator - the character between the two sets
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when the operator is not in ('+','-','*')

      • createSet

        public static java.util.TreeSet<java.lang.Integer> createSet()
        Searches for a set and builds it when user input is valid
        Returns:
        a valid set of type [1,2,3] (TreeSet
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the set doesn't begin with '['
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the next character after '[' is not a number or a right square bracket
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is at less one negative integer
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the set is not ended correctly

      • displayInfo

        public static void displayInfo()
        This procedure displays the rules of the Sets Calculator
